title: ABCC11
content:
**ATP-binding cassette transporter sub-family C member 11**, also **MRP8** (*Multidrug Resistance-Related Protein 8*), is a [membrane transporter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Membrane_transport_protein) that exports certain molecules from inside a cell. It is a [protein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protein) that in humans is encoded by [gene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene) *ABCC11*.

The gene is responsible for determination of human [cerumen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earwax) type (wet or dry ear wax) and presence of underarm [osmidrosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osmidrosis) (odor associated with [sweat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perspiration) caused by [apocrine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apocrine_gland) secretion), and is associated with [colostrum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colostrum) secretion.
sentences: **ATP-binding cassette transporter sub-family C member 11**, also **MRP8** (*Multidrug Resistance-Related Protein 8*), is a [membrane transporter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Membrane_transport_protein) that exports certain molecules from inside a cell.
It is a [protein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protein) that in humans is encoded by [gene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene) *ABCC11*.

The gene is responsible for determination of human [cerumen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earwax) type (wet or dry ear wax) and presence of underarm [osmidrosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osmidrosis) (odor associated with [sweat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perspiration) caused by [apocrine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apocrine_gland) secretion), and is associated with [colostrum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colostrum) secretion.

title: Function
content: The protein encoded by this gene is a member of the superfamily of [ATP-binding cassette](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP-binding_cassette_transporter) (ABC) transporters. ABC proteins transport various molecules across extra- and intra-cellular membranes. ABC genes are divided into seven distinct subfamilies (ABC1, MDR/TAP, MRP, ALD, OABP, GCN20, White). The ABCC11 transporter is a member of the MRP subfamily which is involved in multi-drug resistance. The product of this gene participates in physiological processes involving bile acids, conjugated steroids, and cyclic nucleotides. In addition, a [single nucleotide polymorphism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single_nucleotide_polymorphism) (SNP) in this gene is responsible for determination of human [earwax](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earwax) type and presence of underarm odour. This gene and family member [ABCC12](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ABCC12) are determined to be derived by duplication and are both localized to chromosome 16q12.1. Multiple alternatively spliced transcript variants have been described for this gene.
sentences: The protein encoded by this gene is a member of the superfamily of [ATP-binding cassette](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP-binding_cassette_transporter) (ABC) transporters.
ABC proteins transport various molecules across extra- and intra-cellular membranes.
ABC genes are divided into seven distinct subfamilies (ABC1, MDR/TAP, MRP, ALD, OABP, GCN20, White).
The ABCC11 transporter is a member of the MRP subfamily which is involved in multi-drug resistance.
The product of this gene participates in physiological processes involving bile acids, conjugated steroids, and cyclic nucleotides.

In addition, a [single nucleotide polymorphism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single_nucleotide_polymorphism) (SNP) in this gene is responsible for determination of human [earwax](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earwax) type and presence of underarm odour.
This gene and family member [ABCC12](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ABCC12) are determined to be derived by duplication and are both localized to chromosome 16q12.1.
Multiple alternatively spliced transcript variants have been described for this gene.

title: Molecular genetics
content:
The *ABCC11* [gene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene) is present in the [human genome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_genome) as two [alleles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allele), differing in one [nucleotide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nucleotide) also known as a [single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single-nucleotide_polymorphism). A SNP in the *ABCC11* gene on [chromosome 16](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chromosome_16_(human)) at [base](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nucleobase) position 538 of either a [guanine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guanine) or [adenine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adenine) determines two distinct groups of [phenotypes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype). These respectively code for [glycine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glycine) and [arginine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arginine) in the gene's [protein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protein) product. [Dominant inheritance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominant_inheritance) of the GG or GA [genotype](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotype) is observed while the AA genotype is recessive. The phenotypes expressed by the genotypes include [cerumen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earwax) type (wet or dry ear wax), [osmidrosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osmidrosis) (odor associated with [sweat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perspiration) caused by excessive [apocrine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apocrine_gland) secretion), and possibly [breast cancer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breast_cancer) risk, although there is ongoing debate on whether there is a real correlation of the wet ear wax phenotype to breast cancer susceptibility. The GG or GA genotype produces the wet ear wax phenotype (sticky and brown colored) and acrid sweat odor and is the dominant allele. Note this phenotype requires only the presence of one guanine. The [homozygous](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homozygous) recessive AA genotype produces the dry ear wax phenotype (dry and flaky) and mildly odored sweat.

The alleles containing a guanine produce a protein that is [glycosylated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glycosylation) but alleles containing an adenine are not glycosylated. The resulting protein is only partially degraded by [proteasomes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proteasome). This effect is localized to [ceruminous gland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cerumen) membranes. Because the adenine containing allele protein product is only partially degraded, the remaining functional protein is located on the cell surface membrane which *ABCC11* gene's role in sweat odor is likely in part due to the quantitative dosage of ABCC11 protein.

From an [evolutionary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution) perspective, the implications of cerumen type on [fitness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_(biology)) are unknown. However, odorless sweat in ancient Northern [Eurasian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurasia) populations has been postulated to have an [adaptive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptation) advantage for cold weather. In some nonhuman [mammals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mammal), [mating](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mating) signals via release of an odor enhanced by increased apocrine secretion may be a factor in [sexual selection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_selection).

Physical [human](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human) traits that are controlled by a single gene are [uncommon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_genetics#Human_traits_with_simple_inheritance_patterns). Most human characteristics are controlled by multiple genes ([polygenes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantitative_trait_loci)); *ABCC11* is a peculiar example of a gene with unambiguous phenotypes that is controlled by a SNP. Additionally, it is considered a [pleiotropic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pleiotropy) gene.
sentences: The *ABCC11* [gene](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene) is present in the [human genome](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_genome) as two [alleles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allele), differing in one [nucleotide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nucleotide) also known as a [single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Single-nucleotide_polymorphism).

A SNP in the *ABCC11* gene on [chromosome 16](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chromosome_16_(human)) at [base](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nucleobase) position 538 of either a [guanine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guanine) or [adenine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adenine) determines two distinct groups of [phenotypes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype).

These respectively code for [glycine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glycine) and [arginine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arginine) in the gene's [protein](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protein) product.
[Dominant inheritance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominant_inheritance) of the GG or GA [genotype](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotype) is observed while the AA genotype is recessive.

The phenotypes expressed by the genotypes include [cerumen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earwax) type (wet or dry ear wax), [osmidrosis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Osmidrosis) (odor associated with [sweat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perspiration) caused by excessive [apocrine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apocrine_gland) secretion), and possibly [breast cancer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breast_cancer) risk, although there is ongoing debate on whether there is a real correlation of the wet ear wax phenotype to breast cancer susceptibility.
The GG or GA genotype produces the wet ear wax phenotype (sticky and brown colored) and acrid sweat odor and is the dominant allele.
Note this phenotype requires only the presence of one guanine.
The [homozygous](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homozygous) recessive AA genotype produces the dry ear wax phenotype (dry and flaky) and mildly odored sweat.
The alleles containing a guanine produce a protein that is [glycosylated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glycosylation) but alleles containing an adenine are not glycosylated.
The resulting protein is only partially degraded by [proteasomes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proteasome).
This effect is localized to [ceruminous gland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cerumen) membranes.

Because the adenine containing allele protein product is only partially degraded, the remaining functional protein is located on the cell surface membrane which *ABCC11* gene's role in sweat odor is likely in part due to the quantitative dosage of ABCC11 protein.
From an [evolutionary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution) perspective, the implications of cerumen type on [fitness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_(biology)) are unknown.

However, odorless sweat in ancient Northern [Eurasian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eurasia) populations has been postulated to have an [adaptive](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptation) advantage for cold weather.

In some nonhuman [mammals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mammal), [mating](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mating) signals via release of an odor enhanced by increased apocrine secretion may be a factor in [sexual selection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_selection).

Physical [human](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human) traits that are controlled by a single gene are [uncommon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_genetics#Human_traits_with_simple_inheritance_patterns).

Most human characteristics are controlled by multiple genes ([polygenes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantitative_trait_loci)); *ABCC11* is a peculiar example of a gene with unambiguous phenotypes that is controlled by a SNP.
Additionally, it is considered a [pleiotropic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pleiotropy) gene.

title: Demographics
content:
The history of the migration of humans can be traced back using the *ABCC11* gene alleles. The variation between ear wax in [ethnicities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnic_group) around the world are specifically due to the *ABCC11* gene alleles. It is believed that the derived allele originated in an ancient [East Asian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Asia) population. The gene may have spread as a result of it being a beneficial [adaption](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptation) or through an evolutionary neutral [mutation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation) mechanism that went through [genetic drift](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_drift) events, or through sexual selection.

An analysis of [ancient DNA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_DNA) of [Eastern Hunter Gatherers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_Hunter-Gatherers), [Scandinavian Hunter Gatherers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scandinavian_Hunter-Gatherers), [Western Hunter Gatherers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Hunter-Gatherers) and [Early European Farmers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Early_European_Farmers) found that the derived allele of ABCC11 associated with dry earwax and reduced body odor was absent in all European hunter gatherers, except for a [Western Hunter Gatherer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Hunter-Gatherers) from [Mesolithic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mesolithic) central Europe. The derived allele was absent in the paleolithic hunter gatherer [Kostenki 14](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kostyonki–Borshchyovo#Human_remains), who is deeply related to [Ancient North Eurasians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_North_Eurasians).

The frequency of alleles for dry ear wax is most concentrated in [East Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Asia); most notably [China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China), [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan), [Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Korea), and [Mongolia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mongolia). The allele frequency is highest among the northern [Han Chinese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_Chinese) and [Koreans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koreans); followed by [Mongols](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mongolia), southern Han Chinese, and [Yamato Japanese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yamato_people), respectively. The frequency is low among the [Ryukyuan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryukyuans) and [Ainu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ainu_people). The derived allele is not rare in [South Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Asia), with 54% of [Dravidian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dravidian_people) people from [Tamil Nadu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tamil_Nadu) carrying an AA genotype. A downward gradient of dry ear wax allele phenotypes can be drawn from northern China to southern Asia and an east–west gradient can also be drawn from eastern Siberia to western Europe. The [allele frequencies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allele_frequency) within ethnicities continued to be maintained because the *ABCC11* gene is inherited as a [haplotype](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haplotype), a group of genes or alleles that tend to be inherited as a single unit.

The amount of [volatile organic compounds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volatile_organic_compound) (VOCs) in ear wax was found to be related to variation in ABCC11 [genotype](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotype), which in turn is dependent on ethnic origin. In particular, the rs17822931 genotype, which is especially prevalent in East Asians, is correlated with lower VOC levels. However, VOC levels were not found to vary significantly qualitatively nor quantitatively for most organic compounds by racial group after [Bonferroni corrections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bonferroni_correction), suggesting that it does not result in ethnic differences.
sentences: The history of the migration of humans can be traced back using the *ABCC11* gene alleles.
The variation between ear wax in [ethnicities](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnic_group) around the world are specifically due to the *ABCC11* gene alleles.
It is believed that the derived allele originated in an ancient [East Asian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Asia) population.

The gene may have spread as a result of it being a beneficial [adaption](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptation) or through an evolutionary neutral [mutation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation) mechanism that went through [genetic drift](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_drift) events, or through sexual selection.

An analysis of [ancient DNA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_DNA) of [Eastern Hunter Gatherers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eastern_Hunter-Gatherers), [Scandinavian Hunter Gatherers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scandinavian_Hunter-Gatherers), [Western Hunter Gatherers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Hunter-Gatherers) and [Early European Farmers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Early_European_Farmers) found that the derived allele of ABCC11 associated with dry earwax and reduced body odor was absent in all European hunter gatherers, except for a [Western Hunter Gatherer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_Hunter-Gatherers) from [Mesolithic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mesolithic) central Europe.

The derived allele was absent in the paleolithic hunter gatherer [Kostenki 14](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kostyonki–Borshchyovo#Human_remains), who is deeply related to [Ancient North Eurasians](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancient_North_Eurasians).

The frequency of alleles for dry ear wax is most concentrated in [East Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Asia); most notably [China](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/China), [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan), [Korea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Korea), and [Mongolia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mongolia).

The allele frequency is highest among the northern [Han Chinese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Han_Chinese) and [Koreans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koreans); followed by [Mongols](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mongolia), southern Han Chinese, and [Yamato Japanese](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yamato_people), respectively.
The frequency is low among the [Ryukyuan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ryukyuans) and [Ainu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ainu_people).

The derived allele is not rare in [South Asia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Asia), with 54% of [Dravidian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dravidian_people) people from [Tamil Nadu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tamil_Nadu) carrying an AA genotype.
A downward gradient of dry ear wax allele phenotypes can be drawn from northern China to southern Asia and an east–west gradient can also be drawn from eastern Siberia to western Europe.

The [allele frequencies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Allele_frequency) within ethnicities continued to be maintained because the *ABCC11* gene is inherited as a [haplotype](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haplotype), a group of genes or alleles that tend to be inherited as a single unit.

The amount of [volatile organic compounds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volatile_organic_compound) (VOCs) in ear wax was found to be related to variation in ABCC11 [genotype](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotype), which in turn is dependent on ethnic origin.
In particular, the rs17822931 genotype, which is especially prevalent in East Asians, is correlated with lower VOC levels.

However, VOC levels were not found to vary significantly qualitatively nor quantitatively for most organic compounds by racial group after [Bonferroni corrections](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bonferroni_correction), suggesting that it does not result in ethnic differences.
